entry.title: What your mouth can reveal about your health
entry.summary:
More than a millennium ago, the Persian physician Avicenna suggested that oral maladies could affect the entire body. Today, modern research is showing just how far those effects may reachâ€”revealing that the microbes living on our teeth, tongue, and gums could offer clues to the early detection and prevention of disease throughout the body.
A recent study in JAMA Oncology found that 27 species of oral bacteria and fungi were associated with a 3.5-fold higher risk of developing pancreatic cancer. Using whole-genome sequencing, researchers discovered that patients with evidence of certain microbes in their mouths were significantly more likely to be diagnosed with the disease.
â€œBy profiling bacterial and fungal populations in the mouth, oncologists may be able to flag those most inâ€¦

entry.title: Who was Constantine?
entry.summary: Popular myth has it that in October A.D. 312, on the outskirts of Rome, a moment of inner transformation reshaped the course of Western history: Constantine, on the brink of battle for the imperial throne, converted to Christianity. Constantine reportedly had a strange but powerful vision: a cross of light blazing in the sky, accompanied by the Greek words â€œConquer by thisâ€ more commonly known in Latin as In hoc signo vinces, or â€œIn this sign you will conquer.â€ When he emerged victorious at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge against his rival Maxentius for the throne of the Roman Empire, he interpreted his vision as a divine intervention from God. Christians in the Roman Empire had been a persecuted minority restricted to meeting in secret. Within just a few decades of the emperorâ€™s conversiâ€¦

entry.title: A calendar of New Year celebrations around the world
entry.summary:
New Yearâ€™s Day marks the first day of the Gregorian calendar. As many people gear up to celebrate the start of their New Year at the beginning of January, we take a look at how other cultures and countries mark the beginning of a new year.
Ring in the New Year live from Times Square with star-studded performances, global celebrations, and your favorite hosts! Watch Dick Clarkâ€™s New Yearâ€™s Rockinâ€™ Eve with Ryan SeacrestÂ LIVE December 31 on ABC. This article was adapted from National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The marking of a New Year is an age-old tradition around the world â€” food, fireworks and reflection with friends and family are common threads, but ultimately this varies between different calendars, religions and cultures. While the Gregorian calendar (introduced througâ€¦

entry.title: Too much alone time has a startling effect on the teenage brain
entry.summary:
A new study suggests that lower levels of social interaction during adolescence are linked to differences in brain development, including regions involved in social cognition and decision-making. As teens spend less time with their friends in person, scientists are beginning to uncover how isolation may affect the developing â€œsocial brain." Hereâ€™s what we knowâ€”and when parents should be concerned.
For generations, adolescence has been defined as a time of social connectionâ€”hanging out with friends, dating, and developing bonds outside the family. These interactions arenâ€™t just cultural rites of passage; they help shape how young brains learn to navigate emotions, relationships, and risk.
But that social landscape is changing. In recent years, teens have been spending less timeâ€¦

entry.title: Sudan war: World urged not to ignore 'gruesome sexual violence'
entry.summary: Harrowing new details emerged on Thursday in a UN report detailing targeted sexual violence and summary executions in Sudanâ€™s North Darfur region, attributed to paramilitary fighters who overran the city of El Fasher in late October.

entry.title: Morning Bid: Optics and Oracles
entry.summary: Investors' top focus today is the delayed - and slightly unusual - U.S. consumer price inflation report, which will be an important marker for whether the Federal Reserve is likely to keep cutting interest rates next year.

entry.title: Taiwan rattled by 5.1 magnitude quake, no immediate reports of damage
entry.summary: A 5.1 magnitude earthquake struck 18 km (11 miles) off eastern Taiwan's Hualien city on Thursday, the island's weather administration said, with no immediate reports of damage.

entry.summary: China's defence cooperation with Cambodia and Thailand, including arms trade, "does not target any third party ... and is completely unrelated to the Cambodia-Thailand border conflict," its defence ministry said on Thursday.

entry.title: EU risks losing out to China and US with climate aims, new Czech minister says
entry.summary: The European Union must rethink its climate aims or risk losing out to China and the United States, new Czech Industry Minister Karel Havlicek said as he called on allies to halt the bloc's next-generation emissions trading scheme.

entry.title: Spanish police search laboratory in African swine fever probe
entry.summary: Spanish police searched a state-funded laboratory near Barcelona on Thursday as part of an investigation into the origin of the African swine fever outbreak in the same area, regional police said.

entry.title: China's Momenta teams up with Grab on autonomous driving in Southeast Asia
entry.summary: China's autonomous driving startup Momenta has entered a strategic partnership with Singapore-based Grab , the companies said on Thursday.

entry.title: Tidal wave of Chinese tea brands place bets on winning over American tastebuds
entry.summary: Amanda Wang, co-founder of Chinese fast-growing beverage chain Ningji Lemon Tea, made four research trips to the U.S. before launching Bobobaba, designed to cater specifically to American tastes.

entry.title: China says it is granting new, streamlined rare earth export licences

entry.title: EU must reform or risk irrelevance, Blair and Dimon say
entry.summary: The European Union must reform or risk becoming irrelevant as the rivalry between China and the U.S. sparks a new era without precedent, posing challenges on security, energy, technology and trade, a report led by Tony Blair and Jamie Dimon says.

entry.title: China launches $113 billion free-trade experiment on Hainan island
entry.summary: China on Thursday split off a Belgium-sized island with an economy comparable to a mid-ranked country from the mainland for customs processing, part of a bid to join a major trans-Pacific trade deal and establish a new Hong Kong-style commercial hub.

entry.title: Morning Bid: BoE to make the cut as others stay the course
entry.summary: A look at the day ahead in European and global markets from Tom Westbrook.

entry.title: India streamlines visa rules in boost for Chinese professionals
entry.summary: India has reformed its business visa regime to ease movement of foreign engineers and technicians, the government said in a statement, which will be a boost local firms leaning on Chinese professionals for manufacturing services.

entry.title: China Vanke begins second meeting with holders of 2 billion yuan bond
entry.summary: Cash-strapped China Vanke kicked off a second meeting with holders of a 2 billion yuan ($283.99 million) bond on Thursday, as it scrambles to extend its debt payments with bondholders and banks in an effort to avoid a default.

entry.title: Despite tariffs, China consumer giants push into the US as domestic market stalls
entry.summary: Lured by the promise of richer margins, a wave of Chinese consumer brands is making deeper inroads into American retail to offset sluggish spending at home.

author.name: Casey Hall, Nicholas Brown, Helen Reid

entry.title: US announces massive package of arms sales to Taiwan valued at more than $10 billion
entry.summary: The Trump administration has announced a massive package of arms sales to Taiwan valued at more than $10 billion, including medium-range missiles, howitzers and drones, a move that is sure to infuriate China.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: Tech jitters dent stocks before central banks take centre stage
entry.summary: Asian shares fell on Thursday as the tech sector took a beating on renewed angst about AI spending, while investors braced for a wave of central bank meetings set to underscore policy divergence worldwide.

entry.title: Taiwan says US has initiated $11.1 billion arms sale procedure
entry.summary: Taiwan's defence ministry said on Thursday the U.S. government has initiated the congressional notification procedure for $11.1 billion in arms sales to Taiwan, in a show of support for Taipei which is under increasing military pressure from China.

entry.title: How to see the Southwestâ€™s best red rock formationsâ€”without the crowds
entry.summary:
Located near Grand Junction, Colorado, the Colorado National Monument, or â€œmini-Grand Canyon,â€ has six distinct canyons and 43 trails. Its red rocks, towering formations, and sheer cliffs are visible along the scenic Rim Rock Drive. Beneath the cliffs of western Colorado, a billion years of geologic history unfoldsâ€”and a century-old dream of accessibility still shapes the land.
The Colorado National Monument is blissfully quietâ€”a rare occurrence in national parks in the Southwestâ€”even though it is located a few miles west ofÂ Grand Junction,Â the largest city in western Colorado.
TheÂ Grand CanyonÂ attracted more than four million visitors in 2024, but the Colorado National Monument, also known as the mini-Grand Canyon, welcomes 488,000 peopleÂ a year.Â Â

entry.title: Focus: No small token: Chinese firms convert prized trees, tea into digital assets

entry.title: Republican lawmakers decry Intel's testing of Chinese-linked tools after Reuters report
entry.summary: Republican lawmakers accused Intel this week of threatening U.S. national security after Reuters revealed the chipmaker was evaluating chipmaking equipment made by a company with deep ties to China and overseas units sanctioned by the U.S. government.

entry.title: Can vitamin D lower risk of heart attack?
entry.summary: Vitamin D is thought to play a protective role in heart health, perhaps linked to its anti-inflammatory properties. Now scientists are starting to tease out whether vitamin D supplements might make a difference. Low levels of vitamin D seem to raise your risk of heart attack but scientists are still figuring out whyâ€”and whether supplements might help protect you. Vitamin D has long been known to play an important role in the bodyâ€”and not getting enough of it has beenÂ linked to a number of health issues, including an increased risk of certain types of cancers and autoimmune diseases. But thereâ€™s one link that scientists are still researching. â€œThereÂ is a long association with vitamin â€¦

entry.title: A year after L.A.'s wildfires, survivors share their stories
entry.summary: When Marla Peppers (here with Ryan Shoop and Rick Shoop) saw flames on the ridge above her Altadena home, she recognized the threat before the rest of her family. â€œPack, pack, pack!â€ she shouted. They saved their dog. They lost their cat, their home of almost 22 years, and nearly all their belongings. Today theyâ€™re among more than a dozen fire-displaced families living in an apartment complex and are awaiting construction on their new house, on the same lot as the destroyed one. Nearly 60 square miles burned and 100,000 people were displaced. Now many are holding on to what they foundâ€”in their homes and in themselvesâ€”after the flames had passed. In the era of megadisasters,Â language fails us. We reach for an adjectiveâ€”theÂ worstÂ storm, theÂ deadliestÂ floodâ€¦

entry.title: The global hunt to unlock the healing powers of â€¦ poop
entry.summary:
Inside a petri dish, bacterial colonies (appearing as dark spots) grow from stool collected from a person living in an isolated community near San Marcos Sierras, Argentina. This is one of many such dishes at the Global Microbiome Conservancy (GMbC), founded to collect and preserve microbial diversity worldwide. Scientists have discovered that gut-born bacteria may hold the secret for treatments of everything from IBD to Parkinsonâ€™s disease. Now they just need samples from the people living in the most isolated, nonindustrialized places on Earth. Itâ€™s a messy process, for many reasons.
The first Bajau volunteers pulled up in canoes around 11 a.m. and gathered on a rickety wooden balcony surrounded by the turquoise expanse of the Sulu Sea. They were the intrepid ones. Overâ€¦

entry.title: Were there three Nativity wise menâ€”or twelve?
entry.summary:
"The Magi Journeying" by James Tissot. Tradition has landed on three wise men for the Nativity story but early and medieval Christian sources listed anywhere from two to twelve kings from the east. Early Christian sources differ on how many Magi visited the infant Jesus, and whether they were kings at all.
Few scenes in the Christian imagination are as iconic as the three travelers kneeling before the infant Jesus, their camels waiting patiently as they present gold, frankincense, and myrrh. Yet these visitorsâ€”variously called wise men, astrologers, or kingsâ€”remain among the most mysterious figures in the biblical world.
The Gospel of Matthew, the only canonical source to mention them, provides minimal details about who they were or what compelled them to undertake a long jourâ€¦

entry.title: G7 condemns prosecution of Jimmy Lai, calls for his release
entry.summary: Foreign ministers from the Group of Seven on Wednesday condemned the prosecution of Hong Kong pro-democracy campaigner Jimmy Lai, who was found guilty of collusion with foreign forces this week.

entry.title: China voices support for Venezuela, says it opposes 'unilateral bullying'
entry.summary: China opposes "unilateral bullying" and supports countries in safeguarding their own sovereignty, Foreign Minister Wang Yi told his Venezuelan counterpart on Wednesday, as U.S. President Donald Trump ramps up pressure on the South American country.

entry.title: Finland's prime minister apologises to Asian nations over racism scandal
entry.summary: Finland's prime minister apologised to Asian nations on Wednesday as he sought to contain a growing controversy over derogatory images posted by far-right members of the Nordic country's parliament.

entry.title: Exclusive: How China built its â€˜Manhattan Projectâ€™ to rival the West in AI chips
entry.summary: In a high-security Shenzhen laboratory, Chinese scientists have built what Washington has spent years trying to prevent: a prototype of a machine capable of producing the cutting-edge semiconductor chips that power artificial intelligence, smartphones and weapons central to Western military dominance, Reuters has learned.

entry.title: Time With Others
entry.summary: Given the season, I wondered about the time we spend with others and who we spend our limited hours with. Tags: people, time use

entry.title: Gold forecast to glitter again next year despite biggest gain since 1979
entry.summary: Gold has made its biggest jump since the 1979 oil crisis in 2025 -- with prices doubling in the last two years -- a performance which might previously have meant forecasts of a big correction.

entry.title: Crimean Tatar artist moulds new path through clay in wartime Ukraine
entry.summary: Through her ceramics, Crimean Tatar artist Elvira Demerdzhi finds moments of calm and a sense of home amid the ongoing war in Ukraine.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: At UN, nations pledge people-first digital future, tighter AI safeguards
entry.summary: UN Member States on Wednesday pledged to narrow widening digital divides and put stronger safeguards around artificial intelligence (AI), as the General Assembly concluded a major review of how the world manages the Internet and fast-evolving digital technologies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Fifty days on, Jamaica struggles to rebuild after Hurricane Melissaâ€™s unprecedented destruction
entry.summary: Fifty days have passed since Hurricane Melissa ravaged Jamaica, leaving behind an unprecedented trail of destruction.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aid agencies warn Gaza response at breaking point as Israel urged to lift new restrictions
entry.summary: Humanitarian agencies working in the Occupied Palestinian Territory (OPT) have warned that life-saving aid operations risk collapse unless Israel immediately lifts new barriers that are blocking access and forcing international charities to shut down.

entry.title: China says Philippines distorted facts about incident near disputed atoll
entry.summary: China's defence ministry accused the Philippines on Wednesday of distorting the facts about an incident involving the Chinese coastguard and Filipino fishermen near a South China Sea shoal, a charge Manila strongly rejected.

entry.title: South Korean contractors on Taiwan submarines jailed for leaking documents
entry.summary: A South Korean court found two contractors that worked on Taiwan's submarine programme guilty of leaking designs for torpedo-launching systems, calling the case a potential "diplomatic burden" for Seoul, according to a ruling reviewed by Reuters.

entry.title: Bomba and bioluminescenceâ€”Puerto Rico is full of surprises
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The inhabitants of San Juan arenâ€™t early risers. At 9am, the cityâ€™s streets are largely empty. In the Plaza ColÃ³n, thereâ€™s a cockerel scrabbling about in the flower beds. A kiosk selling coffee and empanadas is untroubled by customers.
â€œWe like a slow start,â€ Laura Ortiz-Villamil confirms as we sit in the shade, the sun already blazing. In front of us is a statue of Christopher Columbus, a crucifix raised in his left hand. Among the first Europeans to barrel over the Atlantic, all eager to get their hands on whatever land they could, he â€˜discoveredâ€™ Puerto Rico in 1493 and immediately claimed it for Spain.

entry.title: Japan visitor arrivals growth strong in November despite China travel warning
entry.summary: The ongoing diplomatic rift between Japan and China has had a muted impact on overall tourist numbers as visitors to Japan grew 10.4% year-on-year in November, the country's tourism board said on Wednesday.

entry.title: Global coal demand hit record high this year but is set to decline by 2030, IEA says.
entry.summary: Global coal demand reached a record high in 2025 but is expected to decline by 2030 as renewables, nuclear power and abundant natural gas squeeze its dominance in power generation, the International Energy Agency said on Wednesday.

entry.title: TikTok monitored Grindr activity through third-party tracker, privacy group alleges
entry.summary: A privacy advocacy group, noyb, filed complaints to Austria's data protection authority on Wednesday against TikTok, Grindr and AppsFlyer, alleging these companies breached regional privacy laws, risking exposure of sensitive data.

entry.title: China's newest aircraft carrier sailed through Taiwan Strait, Taipei says
entry.summary: China's newest and most advanced aircraft carrier, the Fujian, sailed through the Taiwan Strait on Tuesday, Taiwan's defence ministry said, its first transit of the sensitive waterway since formally entering service last month.

entry.title: Shares meander after US jobs data, oil jumps on Venezuela blockade
entry.summary: Global share markets drifted on Wednesday after a mixed U.S. jobs reading failed to move the needle on the rate outlook there, leaving investors awaiting fresh cues for their next moves.

entry.title: AP Top Stories December 16
entry.summary: Here's the latest for Tuesday, December 16th: Hegseth and Rubio brief lawmakers; Zelenskyy says proposals to end war could be presented to Russia within days; 11 firefighters injured in North Carolina; Thousands flock to Tokyo zoo to see pandas leaving for China.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: In Patagonia, penguins are changing how pumas live
entry.summary:
Long absent from Argentinian Patagonia due to over-hunting, pumas have returned and started hunting local Magellanic penguins, which aren't normally part of the big cats' diet. A new study shows how this trend is shaping puma behavior. A natural experiment in a national park in Patagonia shows how the return of a large predator can reshape an ecosystem.
For decades, pumas preyed on sheep from ranches along Argentinaâ€™s coast, and ranchers hunted themâ€”heavily.Pumas disappeared from the landscape. Then, in 2004, conservationists established Monte LeÃ³n National Park in the region. As expected, once the hunting stopped, the big cats came back. And when they returned, they found a new player in their old neighborhood: Magellanic penguins.
What scientists did not anticipate was that â€¦

entry.title: Apple in talks with Indian chipmakers to assemble, package iPhone components, ET reports
entry.summary: Apple is in early discussions with Indian chipmakers to assemble and package components for the iPhone, the Economic Times reported on Wednesday, citing people familiar with the matter.

entry.title: Pakistan's military chief Asim Munir in spotlight over Trump's Gaza plan
entry.summary: Pakistan's most powerful military chief in decades faces the toughest test of his newly amassed powers as Washington pushes Islamabad to contribute troops to the Gaza stabilisation force, a move analysts say could spark domestic backlash.

entry.title: In the ocean's 'twilight zone,' new species await discovery
entry.summary:
Agat Bay, GuamThe sun shimmers across the glassy surface of Blue Hole, a heart-shaped underwater sinkhole, as two divers prepare to descend into its treacherous, turquoise abyss.
Sounds of buckles clicking, straps tightening, and gases swishing through tubes and tanks fill the tiny boat theyâ€™re aboard. The diversâ€”Luiz Rocha, a National Geographic Explorer and an ichthyologist and marine biologist from the California Academy of Sciences, and Mauritius Bell, the academyâ€™s dive safety officerâ€”are gearing up to head 330 feet below the surface, far beyond the reach of most scuba divers.
In this part of the ocean, known as the mesophotic or upper â€œtwilight zone,â€ sunlight is scarce and mysteries abound. Coral reefs thrive in the darkness, harboring life that often appears otherworldly.â€¦

entry.title: 10 breathtaking winter train journeys
entry.summary:
Europeâ€™s Christmas markets hardly need help feeling charming, but somehow trains make them even more so. While the rails carry you past storybook villages and evergreen-studded hills, the journey itself becomes as much a part of the experience as the markets.
Here are 10 of the most breathtaking routes to savor the holidays by railway. Most routes here are covered by the Eurail Pass, but plan in advance for the busy Christmas season.
Route: Zermatt to St. Moritz
The Glacier Express earns its nickname as the worldâ€™s slowest express train, taking eight hours to traverse just 180 miles. But thatâ€™s a feature, not a bug. The panoramic windows frame the Swiss Alps like an IMAX screen, showing offÂ 291 bridges, 91 tunnels, and the stately Landwasser Viaduct.
Time your journeyâ€¦

entry.title: Rotisserie chicken and 10 more of the biggest food trends for 2026
entry.summary:
The coming year promises a wave of culinary ideas shaped by creativity, adaptation and nostalgia. From an ancient condiment to a matcha alternative, here are the food and drink trends to look out for.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Global tastes are ever-shifting, with culinary trends influenced by everything from wellness to supply-chain challenges. Around the world, chefs are seeking out foods that promise both flavour and functional benefits, rediscovering traditional techniques and utilising ingredients that might otherwise be discarded. At the same time, shortages of familiar favourites are nudging drinkers, diners and home cooks towards alternative varieties, while social media propels lesser-known cuisines into the spotlight. Hereâ€™s aâ€¦

entry.title: China ups demand to controlling stake in Panama ports deal, WSJ reports
entry.summary: China has upped its demands and is now pushing for state-owned ship operator Cosco to get a controlling stake in a $22.8 billion ports deal involving two contentious ports near the Panama Canal, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday citing people familiar with the matter.

entry.title: Hong Kong leader raises Jimmy Lai conviction in meeting with China's Xi
entry.summary: Hong Kong's leader said on Tuesday he raised the conviction of pro-democracy campaigner Jimmy Lai in a meeting with China's leader Xi Jinping in Beijing, one day after the media mogul was found guilty of collusion with foreign forces.

entry.title: Why kimchi is king in Vancouver's Korean-Canadian community
entry.summary: Kimjang â€” also known as winter kimchi party â€” is a family affair that traditionally takes place in the year's final months. The traditional preparation and consumption of fermented cabbage has become the connective thread uniting the growing number of Korean-Canadians in British Columbiaâ€™s most multi-cultural city. Here, South Koreaâ€™s most prized culinary possession is a bridging cornerstone, from humble taverns to hip restaurants. This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). Iâ€™m kneeling on the tiled floor of my host Annise Leeâ€™s kitchen, sitting next to three of her pink-rubber-gloved Korean girlfriends. Wafts of pungent fish sauce fill the air. Itâ€™s a brisk November afternoon in the hills of Coquitlam, Vancouverâ€™s unofficial Korea Town, and weâ€™râ€¦

entry.title: How the wrong pillow can wreck your sleep, says science
entry.summary:
Mounting research shows that pillow height and firmness are the strongest predictors of a good nightâ€™s sleep. Your pillow is one of the most powerful tools to help you fall asleep, stay asleepâ€”and even ease your pain and improve posture during waking hours.
If youâ€™ve ever blamed a lousy nightâ€™s rest on stress, room temperature, or your mattress, you might be overlooking the smallestâ€”and arguably most influentialâ€”piece of your sleep setup: your pillow.
It may look like a basic rectangle of fluff, but sleep scientists say your pillow is one of the most powerful levers you have for regulating how quickly you fall asleep, how deeply you stay asleep, and how your neck, spine, breathing, and brain function long after you wake.Â
â€œSleep is a vulnerable state, and the brain and boâ€¦

entry.title: Decoding the lost scripts of the ancient world
entry.summary:
The room we are in isÂ locked. It is windowless and lit from above by a fluorescent bulb. In the hallway outsideâ€”two stories beneath the city of Londonâ€”attendants in dark suits patrol silently, giving the scene an air of cinematic drama. Weâ€™re in the downtown safety deposit center where the Iranian British art collector Kambiz Mahboubian, keeper of one of the worldâ€™s great troves of Near Eastern ancient art, houses some of his more precious pieces under lock and key.
Sitting across from me at a small table, Mahboubian reaches gingerly into a green plastic shopping bag from Waitrose & Partners, the British supermarket chain. From it, he produces a silver beaker covered with friezes long ago hammered out in high relief. As he places the teakettle-size vessel on the table, I can see on itâ€¦

entry.title: China puts anti-dumping tariff of up to 18.9% on imports of pork from the EU
entry.summary: China says it will begin imposing anti-dumping duties of up to 19.8% on imports of pork products from the European Union, after a review that could have resulted in tariffs of up to 62.4%.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: India's exports defy tariffs, strengthen hand in US trade talks
entry.summary: India's exports leapt in November in defiance of U.S. President Donald Trump's steep tariffs, providing fresh leverage in ongoing trade talks with Washington and easing pressure on New Delhi to strike a quick deal.

entry.title: China lowers EU pork tariffs in final ruling after 18-month probe
entry.summary: China on Tuesday dramatically reduced tariffs on European Union pork imports worth over $2 billion in the final ruling of an anti-dumping investigation widely seen as a response to the bloc's duties on Chinese electric vehicles.

author.name: Daphne Zhang , Ella Cao, Corina Pons

entry.title: Japan's last two giant pandas are headed to China and fans just can't bear it
entry.summary: A day after news broke that Japan would soon lose its last two giant pandas to China, thousands of fans flocked to Tokyo's Ueno Zoo on Tuesday to catch a final glimpse, with many bidding the twins a tearful farewell.

entry.title: EU weighs scheme to allow combustion-engine vehicles after 2035, Handelsblatt reports
entry.summary: The European Commission is weighing a new compensation scheme that could allow car makers to sell combustion-engine vehicles beyond 2035, Germany's Handelsblatt newspaper reported on Tuesday, citing senior Commission sources.

entry.title: Americans like artificial Christmas trees even though few are made in US and prices are up
entry.summary: A trade association says new U.S. tariffs increased artificial Christmas tree prices by 10% to 15% this year as tree companies reduced their orders and raised prices to cover the higher import taxes.

entry.title: China seizes smuggled drugs on US tip
entry.summary: China seized 430 kg of smuggled cocaine last month, acting on information from the United States, the Chinese Public Security Ministry said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Stocks struggle before jobs data, central bank meetings
entry.summary: Asian equities tumbled while the dollar drifted near two-month lows on Tuesday, as investors adopted a cautious approach ahead of a slate of U.S. data, including the jobs report, that may help gauge the trajectory for Federal Reserve policy next year.

entry.title: Philippines denounces China's 'dangerous' and 'inhumane' actions against Filipino fishermen
entry.summary: Philippine Defense Secretary Gilberto Teodoro on Tuesday denounced what he described as "dangerous" and "inhumane" actions by Chinese maritime forces against Filipino fishermen in a contested South China Sea shoal last week.

entry.title: Taiwan says its military can respond rapidly to any sudden Chinese attack
entry.summary: Taiwan's military can respond rapidly to any sudden Chinese attack with all units able to operate under a decentralised mode of command without awaiting orders from above, Taipei's defence ministry said in a report to lawmakers.

entry.title: A harrowing tale of the first Americans to summit Everest
entry.summary:
Makalu, flanked by its subsidiary, Makalu II, dominates the scene. At left, Tibetâ€™s 25,640-foot Chomo Lonzo looks across to the Kanchenjunga Massif, which armors the border between Nepal and Sikkim. On the distant right, Indiaâ€™s hot, dry plains appear dimly beyond the clouds. In May of 1963, National Geographic photographer and correspondent Barry C. Bishop was part of the first American team to summit Mount Everest. It was a feat that nearly drove the team mad, and one Bishop recounts in a cover story reprinted here.
This story originally published in the October 1963 issue of National Geographic magazine. See more digitized stories from our archives here.
â€œLute, I think Iâ€™m going mad.â€Â I speak through clenched teeth to Lute Jerstad, lying beside me in the two-man tent. Forâ€¦

entry.title: Oil moves lower on Ukraine talks, weak China data
entry.summary: Oil prices fell in early trading on Tuesday, adding to the previous session's losses, as prospects for a Russia-Ukraine peace deal appeared to strengthen, raising expectations of a potential easing of sanctions.

entry.title: EU to relent on combustion engines ban after auto industry pressure
entry.summary: The European Commission is set to backtrack on the EU's ban on new combustion-engine cars from 2035 by allowing up to 10% of non-electric vehicles after intense pressure from Germany, Italy and Europe's auto sector.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Much of this report is based on data from Wave 170 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from May 5 to 11, 2025. A total of 8,937 panelists responded out of 9,531 who [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: Pew Research Center is a subsidiary of The Pew Charitable Trusts, its primary funder. This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/religion. This report includes new analysis of data from the 2023-24 U.S. Religious Landscape Study (RLS). The RLS was made [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How parents are raising their children, religiously
entry.summary: Learn how often parents discuss religion, types of religious activities their children do and which parent plays a larger role in how their children learn about religion. The post How parents are raising their children, religiously appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Why many U.S. adults are â€˜nones,â€™ and why some former â€˜nonesâ€™ have joined a religion
entry.summary: Find out how adults who were raised as â€œnonesâ€ experienced religion as kids, and why they say they do â€“ or donâ€™t â€“ affiliate with a religion now. The post Why many U.S. adults are â€˜nones,â€™ and why some former â€˜nonesâ€™ have joined a religion appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Why some Americans have left Catholicism, while others stay
entry.summary: Read about how Americans who were raised Catholic experienced religion as kids, as well as their reasons for staying in or leaving the faith. The post Why some Americans have left Catholicism, while others stay appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Why some Americans have left Protestantism, while others stay or join
entry.summary: Find out why US adults who were raised Protestant stay in or leave the faith, and how they experienced religion as kids. Also discover why others join. The post Why some Americans have left Protestantism, while others stay or join appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Why Do Some Americans Leave Their Religion While Others Stay?
entry.summary: A majority of adults still identify with their childhood religion, but 35% donâ€™t. Read about when and why Americans may switch faiths or stay. The post Why Do Some Americans Leave Their Religion While Others Stay? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Jimmy Lai remains beacon of Hong Kong press freedom, say ex-colleagues awaiting his sentencing
entry.summary: Several former colleagues of Hong Kong media mogul Jimmy Lai at the Apple Daily newspaper reacted with dismay at his national security conviction, fearing Lai and other former staffers may be given a heavy sentence but saying he remains an inspiration.

author.name: Jessie Pang, James Pomfret, Angie Teo

entry.title: The forgotten immortal Egyptian queen
entry.summary:
This iconic Egyptian alabaster statue depicts queen Ankhnespepy II with her son, king Pepy II, on her lap. He wears the same distinctive royal headdress later seen on King Tutankhamen, an unmistakable emblem of kingship. But thereâ€™s something unusual about this small sculpture: Ankhnespepy looms twice as large as her son, an intentional subversion of Egyptâ€™s artistic rules, where the pharaoh towered over all but the gods. Ankhnespepy wears a vulture headdress associated with goddesses and queenship. Long before Cleopatra and Hatshepsut, Ankhnespepy II amassed unprecedented political and religious power. Here's how.
In a quiet corner of New Yorkâ€™s Brooklyn Museum, a luminous alabaster sculpture of an Egyptian queen commands attention.Â Â
Just 16 inches high, the sculpture iâ€¦

entry.title: Ample oil supply shields China from impact of Venezuela disruption, for now
entry.summary: The volume of Venezuelan oil already headed to China before the U.S. seized a tanker off the South American country's coast last week, plus a glut of crude in storage and weak demand, will limit the near-term impact of the move in the Chinese market, traders and analysts said.

entry.title: The biggest scientific breakthroughs of the last 25 years
entry.summary:
While the 21st century has been bumpy, it has also ushered in monumental scientific and technological breakthroughs that have changed our world for the better. Advances in medicine have allowed for the creation of unprecedented genetic cures, fusion power has inched closer to reality, weâ€™ve learned more about the ancient past on Earth, and in astronomy, we have glimpsed at things once thought to be impossible to render, like a black hole.
â€œI think there's been a terrific amount of momentum in science in the last quarter century,â€ says France CÃ³rdova, an astrophysicist who currently serves as the president of the Science Philanthropy Alliance and formerly led the U.S. National Science Foundation. â€œI would like to see that accelerated with investment. We really need to let a thousand flâ€¦

entry.title: Was Biblical villain King Herod really a murderous tyrant?
entry.summary:
The Gospel of Matthew records the Massacre of the Innocents (pictured here), supposedly ordered by King Herod after the birth of Jesus. The Roman-backed ruler grew increasingly paranoid and murderous during his reign.
If there is a villain in the Nativity story it is surely Herod, the monarch who supposedly slaughtered thousands of infants and toddlers to exterminate his rival, the baby Jesus. He is reviled in Christian tradition as a cruel tyrantâ€”but while his reputation for ruthlessness is deserved, he may not have slaughtered the children of Bethlehem.
Herod the Great, who ruled Judea from 37 to 4 BCE, lived a life defined by political maneuvering and an unrelenting struggle to secure his power. Herod was not born into a long royal lineage, and he had no priestly backgrouâ€¦

entry.title: The forgotten immortal Egyptian queen
entry.summary:
This iconic Egyptian alabaster statue depicts queen Ankhnespepy II with her son, king Pepy II, on her lap. He wears the same distinctive royal headdress later seen on King Tutankhamen, an unmistakable emblem of kingship. But thereâ€™s something unusual about this small sculpture: Ankhnespepy looms twice as large as her son, an intentional subversion of Egyptâ€™s artistic rules, where the pharaoh towered over all but the gods. Ankhnespepy wears a vulture headdress associated with goddesses and queenship. Long before Cleopatra and Hatshepsut, Ankhnespepy II amassed unprecedented political and religious power. Here's how.
In a quiet corner of New Yorkâ€™s Brooklyn Museum, a luminous alabaster sculpture of an Egyptian queen commands attention.Â Â
Just 16 inches high, the sculpture iâ€¦

entry.title: HEDGE FLOW Hedge funds ditched tech stocks in Japan and Hong Kong last week, says Goldman
entry.summary: Hedge funds sold Hong Kong and Japanese stocks last week, Goldman Sachs said in a note, just before the tech-heavy Hang Seng and Nikkei indices fell in the last two trading sessions on worries over over-inflated tech values.

entry.title: Beyond the Alpsâ€”7 alternative European ski regions to try
entry.summary:
The Pizzalto area of Alto Sangro in Abruzzo is one lesser-known ski destinations in Europe. Skiing in the fringes of Europe opens up some exciting destinations. Head east or to the Pyrenees for affordable mountain resorts offering a rich cultural experience.
This story is created by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As options for the traditional chalet ski break have dwindled and prices risen, venturing to Europeâ€™s far corners and beyond for a ski break can reap rewards. Costs are often lower, while luxury accommodation can be similarly priced to budget options in mainstream European ski resorts. As well as being potentially cheaper, skiing in territory off the beaten track can offer a rich cultural experience, plus better flight routes, less crowded slopes, sunnier dâ€¦

entry.title: UK should make Jimmy Lai's release precondition to closer relations with China, says son
entry.summary: Jimmy Lai's son Sebastien said Britain should make his father's release a precondition to closer relations with China, after the pro-democracy campaigner was found guilty of sedition and collusion by Hong Kong's High Court on Monday.

entry.title: Philippines to protest China's actions that injured Filipino fishermen in South China Sea
entry.summary: The Philippines said on Monday it will protest the Chinese coast guard's "harassment and endangerment" of Filipino fishermen in a South China Sea shoal last week.

entry.title: Taiwan premier refuses to enact opposition-passed spending plans
entry.summary: Taiwan's premier said on Monday he would not enact local government spending plans passed by the opposition-controlled parliament, saying they were fiscally unsound and that lawmakers were welcome to try and remove him in a no confidence vote.

entry.title: China to fall out of Germany's top five export destinations for first time since 2010
entry.summary: China will fall out of Germany's top five export destinations for the first time since 2010, dropping to seventh place as shipments decline 10% to 81 billion euros ($95.04 billion) this year, a government trade agency forecast on Monday.

entry.title: Korea Zinc to build $7.4 bln smelter in US
entry.summary: Korea Zinc said on Monday that it plans to build a smelter to produce key metals and minerals in the United States in a project that would cost $7.4 billion.

entry.title: China strongly dissatisfied with criticism over court verdict on Jimmy Lai
entry.summary: China on Monday said it was strongly dissatisfied and firmly opposes the smears and slanders targeting Hong Kong's judicial system, referring to criticisms by other countries made against the guilty verdict handed down to tycoon Jimmy Lai for his pro-democracy activities.

entry.title: No 'out-of-pocket expenses' for childbirth in China from 2026
entry.summary: China will cover all out-of-pocket expenses related to childbirth next year, said the country's national healthcare security administration, as authorities try to incentivise more young couples to have children.

entry.title: Japan needs a niche approach to get back in the chip game, NTT chairman says
entry.summary: Japan needs to take a niche approach to chip manufacturing - rather than trying to compete on scale and price - as it aims to revive its once-mighty chip industry, the chairman of telecom heavyweight NTT told Reuters in an interview.

entry.title: India's Nov palm oil imports rise as lower prices spur buying
entry.summary: India's palm oil imports edged up in November as refiners took advantage of lower prices, boosting purchases of the tropical oil while reducing imports of the costlier soyoil and sunflower oil, a leading industry body said on Monday.

entry.title: EU yields to pressure from automakers as it rethinks 2035 combustion car ban
entry.summary: The European Commission is expected on Tuesday to reverse the EU's effective ban on sales of new combustion-engine cars from 2035, bowing to intense pressure from Germany, Italy and European automakers struggling against Chinese and U.S. rivals.

entry.title: HSBC's $13.6 billion buyout proposal wins Hang Seng Bank board committee's nod
entry.summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Bank said on Monday an independent board committee found HSBC's $13.6 billion take-private offer to be fair and reasonable, and recommended its minority investors vote in favour of the proposal.

entry.title: Reaction to Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai's guilty verdict in national security trial
entry.summary: Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai was found guilty on Monday of two counts of conspiracy to collude with foreign forces and one count of sedition under a China-imposed national security law that could see him jailed for life.

entry.title: Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai found guilty of collusion with foreign forces
entry.summary: Hong Kong's High Court on Monday found pro-democracy campaigner and tycoon Jimmy Lai guilty of collusion with foreign forces under a China-imposed national security law that could see him jailed for life.

entry.title: China's economy stalls in November as calls for reform grow
entry.summary: China's factory output and retail sales grew at their weakest pace in over a year in November, compounding challenges for policymakers who are struggling to find fresh ways to keep the $19 trillion economy humming.

entry.title: Jimmy Lai is a Hong Kong rags-to-riches media tycoon who became a fierce critic of Beijing
entry.summary: Former Hong Kong media mogul Jimmy Lai, a vocal critic of China's Communist Party, has been convicted of conspiracies of sedition and foreign collusion under a national security law.

entry.title: Stocks slip as traders reduce exposure ahead of central bank meetings, key data
entry.summary: Asian stocks tumbled in early trading on Monday as investors reined in risk-taking at the start of a week sprinkled with central bank decisions and data releases.

entry.title: China, Saudi Arabia agree to strengthen coordination on regional, global matters
entry.summary: China and Saudi Arabia agreed to have closer communication and coordination on regional and international issues, with Beijing lauding Riyadh's role in Middle East diplomacy, statements following a meeting between the nations' foreign ministers on Sunday showed.

entry.title: Roomba maker iRobot files for bankruptcy, pursues manufacturer buyout
entry.summary: iRobot , the maker of the Roomba vacuum cleaner, filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday, saying that it would go private after being bought by Picea Robotics, its primary manufacturer.

entry.title: Korea Zinc board to discuss plan to build smelter under US joint venture, source says
entry.summary: Korea Zinc's board will meet on Monday to vote on a plan to build a smelter to refine key minerals in the U.S. under a joint venture with the U.S. government and companies, a source familiar with the issue said, adding investments would total 10 trillion won ($6.78 billion).

entry.title: Former Hong Kong pro-democracy media mogul Jimmy Lai convicted in landmark national security trial
entry.summary: Jimmy Lai, the former Hong Kong media mogul and outspoken critic of Beijing, has been convicted in a landmark national security trial in the cityâ€™s court.

entry.title: Jimmy Lai verdict updates: Hong Kong court to rule after democracy activist's landmark trial
entry.summary: Jimmy Lai, the Hong Kong media mogul and China critic, faces life in prison if convicted in his years-long trial on national security charges seen as a test case of the city's rule of law.

author.name: Kay Johnson, Kylie MacLellan, Lucy Craymer, Zoe Law

entry.title: 10 of the best new Alpine hotels to book for 2026
entry.summary:
Hotel Kristberg is set beneath the RÃ¼fikopf, the starting point for Lechâ€™s 22km ski circuit, Der Weisse Ring. From reimagined landmarks to debuts by luxe international hotel brands, this seasonâ€™s smartest openings are crowning the peaks of Europeâ€™s Alpine ski hubs.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As the first snows of the season start to fall, mountain towns across the Alps welcome winter visitors with a slew of smart new hotels and reimagined grand dames. The many joys of an Alpine trip, with its mind-calming mountains and chest-puffing pistes, donâ€™t always compensate for the overpriced apartments or unmemorable tour operator chalets. So, itâ€™s a shrewd idea to break with tradition this season and consider a stay in a paint-still-wet hotel inâ€¦

entry.title: Jimmy Lai, Hong Kong tycoon and democratic firebrand who stood up to China
entry.summary: Lai has been in custody for more than five years, much of it in solitary confinement.

entry.title: Jimmy Lai's supporters queue in Hong Kong overnight for verdict
entry.summary: Lai, 78, the millionaire founder of the now-shuttered Apple Daily newspaper and one of the most prominent critics of China's increasingly tight controls under President Xi Jinping, has pleaded not guilty to the three charges against him.

entry.title: Track gorillas in Uganda with the people who protect them
entry.summary:
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
The gorilla is gargantuan. Thereâ€™s a promise of raw power in its chest, supreme agility in arms that ripple with muscle, and wisdom in its dark, deep-set eyes. It looms larger than the trees, taller than the mountains, dwarfing even the sun â€” a canary yellow sphere sketched in the corner of the page.
Ten-year old Akankwasaâ€™s drawing captures a mythic vision of the forest, winning first prize in a local competition run by the Gorilla Organization. The charityâ€™s Ugandan arm works from a simple conviction: that change begins in classrooms. With fewer than a dozen staff, they support 28 schools that cling to the edges of the gorillasâ€™ kingdom, the mist-cloaked slopes of Mgahinga and Bwindi National Parks in the countryâ€¦

entry.title: Inside the world's biggest pilgrimage for the Virgin Mary
entry.summary:
The annual pilgrimage to the worldâ€™s most visited shrine to the Virgin Mary, stretches from the rural reaches of Mexico to the Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe on a small hill in the capital, ending in a tunnel with a floor that glides slowly along a conveyer belt towards an image of the Madonna. Thirteen million people were expected to make the journey this year for the December 12 feast day, government officials said, many by anachronistic means: on foot through the mountain passes outside of the city, on bikes along backwoods highways, crowded onto the beds of festooned tractor trailers, and on their knees for the last stretch.
At the basilica, in a space behind the altar of the circular modern building, the pilgrims funnel onto the moving walkway and tilt their heads up. Hangâ€¦

entry.title: Philippines says fishermen hurt, boats damaged by China in South China Sea
entry.summary: The Philippine coast guard said on Saturday that three Filipino fishermen had been wounded and two fishing vessels suffered "significant damage" when Chinese coast guard ships fired water cannon in a disputed South China Sea shoal.

entry.title: China holds low-key Nanjing Massacre memorial despite Japan tensions
entry.summary: China held a low-key memorial ceremony on Saturday for the 1937 Nanjing Massacre, with President Xi Jinping not attending, despite a diplomatic crisis between Beijing and Tokyo over Taiwan.

entry.title: Huawei's latest handset uses improved China-made chip, report shows
entry.summary: The Kirin 9030, the chip that powers Huawei Technologies' latest flagship Mate 80 series handset, has been manufactured by China's top foundry SMIC with an improved version of 7 nanometres, which is still behind TSMC and Samsung, Canadian research firm TechInsights said.

entry.title: US lawmaker demands details on Trump's decision to sell Nvidia H200 chips to China
entry.summary: U.S. lawmaker John Moolenaar, the chair of the U.S. House of Representatives' bipartisan select committee focused on China, on Friday asked Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick to explain the details of President Donald Trump's decision to allow Nvidia to sell its H200 chips to China.

entry.title: Humanoid robots take center stage at Silicon Valley summit
entry.summary: Hundreds of robotics firms and investors gathered at the Humanoids Summit in Silicon Valley as generative AI breathes new life into robots that walk, talk and move like humans.

entry.title: US forces raided ship headed to Iran from China in Indian Ocean, WSJ says
entry.summary: A U.S. special operations team in the Indian Ocean raided a ship headed to Iran from China last month and seized military-related articles, the Wall Street Journal reported on Friday, citing U.S. officials.

entry.title: Humanoid robots take center stage at Silicon Valley summit, but skepticism remains
entry.summary: The commercial boom in artificial intelligence has sparked interest in humanoid robots. Venture capitalist Modar Alaoui, founder of the Humanoids Summit, gathered over 2,000 people, including top engineers from Disney and Google, to showcase technology and discuss the future of humanoids.

entry.title: What happened to the Ark of the Covenant? Hereâ€™s what we know.
entry.summary:
In A.D. 70, after a brutal, months-long siege, Roman troops under General Titus stormed Jerusalem to crush a Jewish revolt against imperial rule. The city fell, and the Second Templeâ€”the spiritual heart of Judaismâ€”was plundered and burned. Roman soldiers seized its sacred treasures. However, one crucial artifact was noticeably missing: The Ark of the Covenant. Jewish historian Flavius Josephus, an eyewitness to the events, wrote an account a few years later in The Jewish War, detailing the templeâ€™s destruction and the triumphal parade in Rome that followed:
â€œThe golden table, of the weight of many talents; the candlestick also, that was made of gold... and the last of all the spoils, was carried the Law of the Jews.â€™â€™ Amongst all the treasures, there is no mention of the ark, in whichâ€¦

entry.title: New mantis species dances like a snake
entry.summary: This male snake-tail mantis, Ameles serpentiscauda, has three simple eyes (ocelli) visible between its antennae, which mantises usually use during night flights to navigate using starlight. The short, non-functional wings, characteristic of this species, do not allow this mantis to fly at all. The snake-tail mantis shows thereâ€™s more to these insects than just cannibalism.  Female praying mantises are notorious for eating their mates during or after sex. Now, scientists have discovered a dwarf mantis species in which males avoid this fate with an elaborate dance performance. During this love dance, the male moves its abdomen in various ways: sometimes sinuously like the coils of a serpent and sometimes jerkily like the tail of a rattlesnake. This unique behavior inâ€¦

entry.title: How to start birding, according to Amy Tan
entry.summary: Writer Amy Tan scourers her yard in Sausalito, California for birds. Her recently published book, The Backyard Bird Chronicles, documents her evolution as a birder. The celebrated author wrote a bestseller on birding. This is how she got started. Amy Tan has always loved nature. From the age of eight, the novelist was plucking snakes and lizards from a creek near her suburban home in Northern California. But birds entered the picture much later. In 2016, at 64, Tan began taking classes on how to draw and journal about birds. In the backyard of her Bay Area home, her subjects included hummingbirds, jays, sparrows, finches, warblers, and owls. Her lovely drawings and witty journal entries were published last year in her best-selling book, The Backyard Bird Chronicles. â€¦

entry.title: See the best of Oklahoma City's stretch of Route 66
entry.summary: Once an Old West outpost for roving cattle ranchers, these days, you're more likely to see Oklahoma City locals in paint-splattered clothes than on horseback. Though most travellers will visit this state capital for its fascinating history, its thriving creative scene is equally worth exploring. Most of it unfolds along the 51.5 miles of Route 66 within the city's limits. This part of America's most famous highway â€” which marks its centennial in 2026 â€” is known for its quirky murals, neon sign-filled neighbourhoods and art deco architecture. Plus, the route is home to the National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum, which holds an impressive collection of art depicting the history and culture of the American West. Here are some must-see attractions along Oklahoma City's stretch of the 'Motheâ€¦

entry.title: How the next generation is reshaping Shanghai
entry.summary:
Penicillin Bar makes inventive cocktails using recycled waste ingredients. A new generation in this storied Chinese megacity is eschewing the fast-paced lifestyles of their parents and embracing fun, freedom and living life to the full â€” and Shanghai is adapting in interesting ways.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
On a bend in the Bund riverfront, baroque, pillared palaces from Shanghaiâ€™s days as a high-society hub sparkle like diamonds in a dÃ©colettage. Across the water, the sun ricochets off 21st-century skyscrapers half a kilometre tall. And between them, thousands of people swarm the boardwalk, scrum for photos and pour out of ritzy restaurants to take in the panorama thatâ€™s become a symbol of the cityâ€™s might.
The Bund is a must-seâ€¦

entry.title: Inside the iconic Waldorf Astoria in New York
entry.summary:
The Waldorf Astoria used to be two separate hotels that were connected via a passageway named Peacock Alley. This Gilded Age grande dame was a pioneer in luxury hotels, and stood witness to historic events, social change, and star-studded galas. Now itâ€™s back after an eight-year renovation.
The Waldorf Astoria New York closed temporarily in 2017 in preparation for an extensive renovation and many people, like myself, came to get one last look at this storied New York City hotel.
Perhaps it was to have a cocktail within its famous Peacock Alley or order a Waldorf salad or marvel at its lobby piano that once belonged to resident Cole Porter.
Established during the Gilded Age, this iconic property has witnessed historic events, social changes, and star-studded galas. It intrâ€¦

entry.title: 6 archaeological discoveries that amazed the world in 2025
entry.summary:
Cutting-edge scientific tools reshaped archaeology this year: Ancient DNA sequencing reconstructed the ancestry of an Egyptian who lived at the dawn of the pyramids. Satellite images captured traces of massive ancient hunting traps strewn across the Andes. And underwater mapping brought sunken World War II warships back into view and uncovered a submerged port that may hold clues to finding Cleopatraâ€™s final resting place.
But many of 2025â€™s biggest discoveries also came from classic excavations. In Belize, a dig at a pyramid at Caracol unearthed a chamber containing a royal Maya burial. Near Egyptâ€™s Valley of the Kings, archaeologists unearthed the last missing tomb of an 18th-Dynasty pharaoh.
Taken together, they hint at how much human history still lies hiddenâ€”in deep waters, â€¦

entry.title: Discover Buenos Aires through these 5 dazzling bookstores
entry.summary:
A thoughtfully designed bookstore has the kind of magic that transcends language. This is especially true in Argentinaâ€™s capital city of Buenos Aires, which has long been celebrated as one of the worldâ€™s great literary cities with more bookstores per capita than almost anywhere else.
The city is most famous for El Ateneo Grand Splendid, which is often recognized as one of the worldâ€™s most beautiful bookstores. But for those who know where to look, the city contains much more than this single dazzling literary homage.Â
(This is the world's most beautiful bookstore)
Despite years of economic and political instability, and limitless distractions caused by the digital age, the bookstores of Buenos Aires are flourishing at a time when they are disappearing everywhere else. This iâ€¦

entry.title: Danish intelligence report warns of US military threat under Trump

entry.title: China's Changan Automobile adds Italy and Spain to its European markets
entry.summary: Chinese automaker Changan Automobile is expanding into Italy and Spain with the launch of two fully electric models, followed next year by their plug-in hybrid versions.

entry.title: Nasdaq submits new plan with more power to block IPOs vulnerable to manipulation
entry.summary: Nasdaq filed a new rule on Friday that would allow the exchange to block IPOs even when companies meet all listing standards if it detects red flags that could make a company's stock vulnerable to manipulation.

entry.title: EU to impose 3 euro duty on small e-commerce parcels from July 2026
entry.summary: European Union finance ministers agreed on Friday to set a 3 euro ($3.52) custom duty on low-value parcels arriving in the bloc, part of an attempt to crack down on cheap Chinese e-commerce imports such as from online retailers Shein and Temu.

entry.title: From mud homes to joyful songs: Living heritage on the global stage
entry.summary: Drums and celebration filled a hall in New Delhi, India, as communities from across the world saw their traditions recognised, from Panamaâ€™s Quincha homes built by collective hands, to Yemenâ€™s Hadrami Dan gatherings where poetry and music are created in the moment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Peace falters as fighting in eastern DR Congo raises fears of regional war
entry.summary: Civilians across eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) are facing collapsing health services and mass displacement as fighting spreads, undermining recent peace efforts and raising fears of a wider regional crisis.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN environment assembly wraps up in Nairobi
entry.summary: The seventh session of the United Nations Environment Assembly (UNEA-7) concluded in Nairobi, Kenya, on Friday with Member States adopting 11 resolutions, three decisions and a ministerial declaration aiming to advance solutions for a more resilient planet.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Deep concerns for Palestinians amid intense Israeli raids in occupied West Bank
entry.summary: The UN human rights office, OHCHR, has expressed alarm at reports of a so-called â€œsettler roadâ€ being built in the occupied West Bank.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN sounds alarm over rising demands on water resources as scarcity increases
entry.summary: Pressure on freshwater resources is growing as demand increases in regions marked by scarcity, the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) said in a report published on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN missionâ€™s exit marks milestone in Iraqâ€™s post-conflict transition
entry.summary: After more than two decades working alongside Iraq through war, political upheaval and the fight against ISIL terrorists, the UN Assistance Mission there (UNAMI) ends its mandate on 31 December â€“ a closure its top official describes as â€œhonourable, dignified, and earnedâ€.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors debate deepening crisis in eastern DR Congo
entry.summary: The UN Security Council meets at 10 AM in New York to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), amid intensified fighting and mass displacement. UN Peacekeeping chief Jean-Pierre Lacroix is due to brief on recent peace efforts â€“ including the Washington Accords between the DRC and Rwanda, signed just days before violence surged again, heightening fears of a worsening humanitarian emergency and regional spillover. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. Find our recent reporting here on the crisis and go here for all our in-depth meeting coverage.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war: Aid teams say deal struck to reach stricken El Fasher
entry.summary: In Sudan, deep concerns persist for the many tens of thousands of people believed to still be trapped in El Fasher in the Darfur region, but UN aid agencies believe they may soon get access to the embattled city.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Morning Bid: Is Santa Claus coming to town?
entry.summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jay Powell buoyed markets by executing that most rare of monetary policy moves: the dovish â€˜hawkish cutâ€™. But the spectre of AI anxiety threatens to hold off a â€œSanta Clausâ€ rally.

entry.title: China says it expelled Philippine aircraft, vessels near disputed atolls
entry.summary: China said on Friday it had driven away a Philippine aircraft and multiple vessels near disputed atolls in South China Sea, in the latest in a series of confrontations in the strategic waterway in recent years.

entry.title: China's Jiangxi Copper sweetens bid for UK-listed SolGold to $1.13 billion
entry.summary: SolGold said on Friday it was "minded to recommend" an improved offer from its top shareholder, Jiangxi Copper that values the gold and copper miner at about 842 million pounds ($1.13 billion), amid a global race for copper assets.

entry.title: Hong Kong leader says fire probe expected to conclude within 9 months
entry.summary: Hong Kong will seek to wrap up an independent investigation into a fire that killed at least 160 people in the Asia financial centre within nine months, the city's leader said on Friday.

entry.title: Broadcom falls as margin pressures add to AI payoff jitters
entry.summary: Broadcom shares fell nearly 5% before the market open on Friday after the chipmaker said its margins would fall due to a higher mix of AI revenue, adding to worries about the payout from AI.

entry.title: Google to build subsea cables in Papua New Guinea under Australia defence treaty
entry.summary: Alphabet's Google will build three subsea cables in Papua New Guinea, which the largest Pacific Island nation said was funded by Australia under a mutual defence treaty, in a key upgrade to its digital backbone.

entry.title: Asia Gold: India gold discounts widen as prices hit record high; China demand muted
entry.summary: Gold discounts in India widened this week as demand fell despite the wedding season after prices scaled record highs, while Chinese demand remained muted amid volatility and high spot prices.

entry.title: Hong Kong's legal clampdown on tycoon and China critic Jimmy Lai
entry.summary: Hong Kong's High Court will hand down a verdict in the trial of media tycoon and China critic Jimmy Lai on Monday.

entry.title: Focus: China's small bank mergers shrink sector but raise financial risks
entry.summary: Many of China's newly merged small banks have seen profits fall and capital buffers shrink over the past year, a Reuters review of data showed, testing Beijing's record consolidation drive designed to avert risks in its $8 trillion small banking sector.

entry.title: Exclusive: India frees up visas for Chinese professionals in key step to boost ties
entry.summary: India has cut red tape to speed business visas for Chinese professionals, two officials said, a major step to boost ties between the Asian giants and end chronic delays that cost output worth billions of dollars because of scarce technicians.

entry.title: A Chinese whistleblower now living in the US is being hunted by Beijing with help from US tech
entry.summary: Retired Chinese official Li Chuanliang fled to the U.S. seeking asylum, fearing persecution from the Chinese government.

entry.title: Trump signs executive order aiming to block state AI regulations
entry.summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order Thursday aimed at blocking states from creating their own AI regulations, saying the burgeoning industry risks being stifled by a patchwork of onerous rules while competing with China for supremacy.

entry.title: JD.com pledges $3.12 billion housing support for couriers
entry.summary: JD.com , one of China's largest e-commerce firms, pledged 22 billion yuan ($3.12 billion) in housing support for its army of couriers, as competition intensifies in the instant retail market.

entry.title: Verdict for Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai's national security trial expected next Monday
entry.summary: Hong Kong's High Court will hand down a verdict against pro-democracy campaigner Jimmy Lai next Monday, according to a notice on the city's judiciary website, in a landmark national security trial that has drawn international scrutiny.

entry.title: Cathay passenger arrested after trying to open door mid-flight from Boston to Hong Kong
entry.summary: Hong Kong police said on Friday they had arrested a passenger who was on Cathay Pacific's CX811 flight from Boston to Hong Kong, after the carrier said the individual tried to open an aircraft door mid-flight on December 10.
